clinical_study.brief_title: Ultrasound-assisted Versus Conventional Landmark-guided Spinal Anesthesia in Patients With Abnormal Spinal Anatomy
clinical_study.official_title: Ultrasound-assisted Versus Conventional Landmark-guided Spinal Anesthesia in Patients With Abnormal Spinal Anatomy

brief_summary.textblock: Spinal anesthesia can be challenging in patients with lumbar scoliosis or previous lumbar spine surgery. This study aims to evaluate whether the use of the ultrasound-assisted spinal anesthesia reduces the number of passes required to successful dural puncture compared with the conventional surface landmark-guided technique in patients with abnormal spinal anatomy.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Intraoperative (from the first insertion of needle to patient's skin, until the completion of spinal anesthetic injection)
primary_outcome.description: the number of forward advancements of the spinal needle in a given interspinous space, i.e., withdrawal and redirection of spinal needle without exiting the skin

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of spinal needle insertion attempts
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Intraoperative (from the first insertion of needle to patient's skin, until the completion of spinal anesthetic injection)
secondary_outcome.description: the number of times the spinal needle was withdrawn from the skin and reinserted

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 1 day (time taken for establish the landmark, from start of palpation/US scanning to completion of palpation/scanning)
secondary_outcome.description: In group L, time from start of palpation to completion of the process, as declared by the anesthesiologist. In group U, time from placement of the ultrasound probe on the skin to the completion of markings.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time taken for performing spinal anesthetic
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Intraoperative (from insertion of the needle to the completion of injection)
secondary_outcome.description: time from needle insertion to the completion of injection

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 5, 10, 15 minutes after the completion of spinal anesthetic injection
secondary_outcome.description: thoracic dermatome level of sensory block assessed by loss of cold sensation tested with 2% chlorhexidine swab

secondary_outcome.measure: Incidence of radicular pain, paraesthesia, and blood tapping in the spinal needle
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Intraoperative (from the first insertion of needle, until the completion of spinal anesthetic injection)
secondary_outcome.description: Incidence of radicular pain, paraesthesia, and blood tapping in the spinal needle during the spinal anesthesia procedure

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Patients will be asked immediately after the completion of spinal anesthesia
secondary_outcome.description: 11-point verbal rating scale (0=no pain, 10=most pain imaginable)

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Patients will be asked immediately after the completion of spinal anesthesia
secondary_outcome.description: 11-point verbal rating scale (0=no discomfort, 10=most discomfort imaginable)

arm_group.description: Preprocedural ultrasound-assisted paramedian spinal anesthesia will be performed. 0.5% heavy bupivacaine will be injected to intrathecal space for spinal anesthesia.
Landmark-guided spinal anesthesia will be performed, via either midline or paramedian approach. 0.5% heavy bupivacaine will be injected to intrathecal space for spinal anesthesia.

intervention.description: A preprocedural ultrasound scanning will be done, and skin marking will be made. The needle entry point and insertion angle will be determined based on ultrasound scanning. Spinal anesthesia will be performed via paramedian approach.
Spinal anesthesia will be done using conventional landmark-guided technique.

0.5% heavy bupivacaine will be administered into intrathecal space. The dose of local anesthetic injected for spinal anesthesia will be at the discretion of the attending anesthesiologist. The dose range of intrathecal bupivacaine will be between 12 and 16 mg.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Adult patients scheduled to undergoing elective orthopedic surgery under spinal anesthesia,
- with ASA physical status classification I, II, III,
- and with (1) or (2)
1. documented scoliosis in preoperative L-S-Spine X-ray (Cobb abgle > 10 degree)
2. previous history of lumbar spinal surgery
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients with contraindication to spinal anesthesia (coagulopathy, local infection, allergy to local anesthetic)
- Patients with morbid cardiac diseases
- Pregnancy

reference.citation: Chin KJ, Perlas A, Chan V, Brown-Shreves D, Koshkin A, Vaishnav V. Ultrasound imaging facilitates spinal anesthesia in adults with difficult surface anatomic landmarks. Anesthesiology. 2011 Jul;115(1):94-101. doi: 10.1097/ALN.0b013e31821a8ad4.
